title.narrative: CHILD SURVIVAL

description.narrative: By 2016, more effective and equitable health polices and service provision systems deliver quality high impact interventions for reducing preventable child deaths and stunting, which contributes to Child Health, Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Health And Emergencies, Health Systems Strengthening, Immunization, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Maternal And Newborn Health, Micronutrients, Nutrition And Hiv, Nutrition â€“ General, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2016, government capacity to deliver equitable quality child survival and development services reduces child mortality and morbidity.

mailing-address.narrative: 1st Floor UN Place(Annex) Matsitama Road P O Box 20678 Gaborone

Technical assistance - Treatment of severe acute malnutrition
Vitamin A supplementation in early childhood (children under 5)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2016, more effective and equitable health polices and service provision systems deliver quality high impact interventions forreducing preventable child deaths and stunting

description.narrative: In 2016, UNICEF Botswana supported: development of newborn care clinical guidelines; a successful switch from tOPV to bOPV vaccine in all 28 health districts; Measles-Rubella vaccination reaching 674,140 children aged 9 months to 14 years (95.4% coverage); and data analysis to inform the national nutrition response to the El-nino drought. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:16/01/2017

title.narrative: Number of new vaccines introduced

actual.value: 2016:7 vaccines introduced: Pentavalent and 2nd measles vaccine in 2010, Rotavirus and pneumococcal vaccines in 2012, HPV and IPV rolled-out in 2015, and Measles-Rubella in 2016

title.narrative: Number of key guidelines and standards on nutrition developed/reviewed

actual.value: 2016:Target met by 2014. (National Nutrition Strategy and Growth Monitoring and Promotion guidelines)

title.narrative: Number of districts supported to conduct bottleneck analysis on key maternal and child health and nutrition indicators for equity programming
Percentage of districts that introduced IPV

actual.value: 2016:100%. Introduced in November 2015 in all districts.

title.narrative: / % of communities with capacities to provide IYCF counselling service [as defined by country]
Proportion of children under five sleeping under ITNs
Proportion of children 6-59 months receiving two doses of Vitamin A supplementation

actual.value: 2016:75.2%, being coverage for semester 1 2016. Semester 2 data is not yet available. Target not reached for 2016

title.narrative: Proportion of children under one year immunised with DPT3 vaccine

actual.value: 2016:91% (2015). 2016 data not ready, but unlikely to meet the 96% target

title.narrative: High Level Multisectoral Nutrition platform or coordination mechanisms functional

actual.value: 2016:Slow progress. Technical Officers in key Ministries have outlined way forward. To continue in 2017

title.narrative: National nutrition supplies monitoring plan developed and utilized
Appropriate, full-provision national legislation on marketing of breast milk substitutes in place, monitored and enforced
Availability of a new or revised policy for home visits of newborns

actual.value: 2016:Yes. Though implementation is severely constraint by lack of transport and human resource capacity limitations
